messageBody:
Dear Ole,

I understand your suggestion to be about efficiency. To the degree that
there is redundancy between the code and the tests, it feels like a waste of
time, and you'd like to eliminate that waste.

One of the principles involved in testing is double checking--say something
in two different ways and if they match, you have a good chance you are
saying what you intend to say. The philosophical problem I have with
generating code from tests, or test from code, or tests and code from some
other notation, is that it ignores double checking. The baby of
double-checking goes out with the bathwater of redundancy.

I like the JUnitFactory tests because they give me an independent
perspective on my code. Manually inspecting generated tests gives me a
measure of double checking. "Really?!? factorial(100) == 0???"

Programming language design seemed for many years to be the quest for a
notation so clear that programmers couldn't make mistakes. The
small-but-growing popularity of developer testing seems to me to be evidence
that double checking is a more fruitful strategy for achieving reliable
software.

All of that said, I agree with the desire for less redundant test notations.
@Theory, for example, seems to promise more confidence/line of test code.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

_____

Subject: Re: [junit] Future of testing tools



Hi Kent,

We had a pretty good discussion around this
on this thread:

http://www.nabble.
<http://www.nabble.com/100---Method-Testing-and-Generating-Unit-Tests-tf2902
785.html> com/100---Method-Testing-and-Generating-Unit-Tests-tf2902785.html

I think we could summarize it to having a design tool
that helps design the architecture of the system,
perhaps narrowed by concern area and architectural
layer (Presentation, application, business,
integration ,data) and then generates tests that
enumerate all the corner and edge cases, helping the
designer / developer validate the system.

Personally I would like to see it combined with
something like this:

http://www.eclipse.
<http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-EMF-Codegen-with-OCL/article.html>
org/articles/Article-EMF-Codegen-with-OCL/article.html

Something that generates both the application code and
the corresponding test cases. Then makes it as simple
as possible for the users / solution recipients to
validate the system.

I'm going to summarize the thread in a little apache
licensed eclipse documentation plugin just elaborating
on the enumeration methodology, etc. discussed in the
thread. I'll post back when it's done.

BTW - Thanks a gazillion (To Eric as as well) for
writing "Contributing to Eclipse" and JUnit. I think
calling it "Briliant work" would be an understatement.

Cheers,
- Ole
